questions.question: Question 1: Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of chloramphenicol, especially in premature 
infants. It develops due to the developmental deficiency of the enzyme glucoronyl transferase. This 
enzyme metabolizes chloramphenicol in neonates. Its deficiency leads to an inability to excrete 466 
Sold by @itachibot unconjugated drugs adequately through renal excretion. The initial symptoms are: • Vomiting • Refusal to suck • Irregularly rapid respiration • Periods of cyanosis. After 1-2 days: • Flaccid baby • Hypothermia • Ashen-gray color skin discoloration If there is a recovery, usually there are no sequelae.

questions.question: Question 2: Chloramphenicol acts by binding to:
questions.explanation:
Chloramphenicol acts by binding to the 50s ribosomal subunit. It inhibits the binding of amino acid containing tRNA to acceptor site on 50s subunit of the 
ribosome. This prevents peptide bond formation by inhibiting the interaction 
between peptidyltransferase enzyme and the amino acid.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient who was diagnosed with meningitis is on chloramphenicol therapy. Which of the 
following blood dyscrasias as a side effect of this drug?
questions.explanation:
The patient is most likely to have aplastic anemia, as it is the most common blood dyscrasia 
associated with the use of chloramphenicol. It can lead to fatal pancytopenia that has a high rate 
of mortality. Hematological toxicities of chloramphenicol include: • Dose-related toxicity - pancytopenia (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia) • Idiosyncratic response - aplastic anemia Blood dyscrasias occurring with chloramphenicol: • Aplastic anemia (70%) • Hypoplastic anemia • Agranulocytosis • Thrombocytopenia Chloramphenicol remains an alternative drug for the treatment of meningitis caused by H. 
influenzae, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae in developing countries and also in patients who 
have a severe allergy to -lactams. 467 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following antibiotics structurally resembles aminoacyl t-RNA and inhibits the 
protein synthesis by premature termination?
questions.explanation:
Puromycin structurally resembles aminoacyl t-RNA and inhibits the protein synthesis by 
premature termination. It is used as an antibiotic in cell cultures. Option A: Tetracycline binds to the 30s ribosome and prevents attachment of aminoacyl t-RNA to 
the acceptor site. Option B: Chloramphenicol binds to the 50s subunit of the ribosome and inhibits the binding of 
amino acid containing tRNA to the acceptor site on 50s subunit of the ribosome. Option D: Erythromycin acts by interfering with translocation at the 50s ribosome.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following groups of antibiotics has additional anti-inflammatory and 
immunomodulatory activities?
questions.explanation:
Macrolides are a group of antibiotics that have additional anti-inflammatory and 
immunomodulatory activities. They are being investigated and used in pulmonary diseases for their immunomodulatory 
properties. Examples of macrolide antibiotics: • Erythromycin • Azithromycin • Clarithromycin

questions.question:
Question 6: An unvaccinated child diagnosed with diphtheria is initiated erythromycin therapy. This drug 
acts by interfering with:
questions.explanation:
Erythromycin acts by interfering with translocation at the 50s ribosome. It does not inhibit the peptide bond formation but the translocation step is inhibited where the 
peptidyl t-RNA molecule moves from the acceptor site on the ribosome to the peptidyl donor site.

questions.question: Question 7: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients 
the drug of choice is doxycycline. An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is 
chloramphenicol. 468 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state is erythromycin. Erythromycin for 7 days is very effective for eradicating the diphtheria carrier state or acute 
infections.

questions.question: Question 9: What is the rationale for the use of erythromycin in a patient with diabetic gastroparesis?

options.a: It increases cAMP and increases intestinal motility
options.b: It decreases bacterial count in intestinal hypomotility
options.c: It binds to adenyl cyclase and increases intestinal motility
options.d: It binds to motilin receptors and stimulates intestinal motility

questions.explanation:
Erythromycin can be used in diabetic gastroparesis as it binds to motilin receptors and stimulates 
intestinal motility. It has been used in conditions with hypomotility of the gastrointestinal tract like in postoperative 
ileus to promote peristalsis and to increase gastric emptying. Erythromycin is used off-label as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients 
with diabetic gastroparesis.

questions.question:
Question 10: The chest x-ray of a patient who presented with fever and cough with expectoration is shown 
below. Following discussion, a lincosamide antibiotic is prescribed. Which of the following 
will you choose?
questions.explanation:
Clindamycin, a lincosamide is used in the management of lung abscess and anaerobic lung and 
pleural space infections. Clindamycin is a congener of lincomycin and binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes and 
inhibits protein synthesis. Option A: Telithromycin is a ketolide antibiotic. Option B: Spectinomycin is an aminocyclitol antibiotic that binds to the 30S subunit of ribosomes 
and inhibits protein synthesis. Option D: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is a serious adverse effect you would consider as a possibility in a 
patient receiving clindamycin?
questions.explanation:
Clindamycin use is to be limited because of the risk of pseudomembranous colitis. Pseudomembranous colitis is a lethal syndrome caused by Clostridium difficile due to alteration 
in normal intestinal microbiota. It is characterized by fever, watery diarrhea and increased 
peripheral white blood cell count. Metronidazole and oral vancomycin are used in the treatment 
of this condition. Drugs causing pseudomembranous colitis are: • Penicillins • Clindamycin • Rifaximin 469 
Sold by @itachibot • Tetracycline (rare side effect) • Erythromycin

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements about streptogramins is true?

options.a: Quinupristin-dalfopristin combination is not active against gram-positive cocci
options.b: Synergistic activity of quinupristine and dalfopristine has bactericidal action
options.c: Quinupristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes
options.d: Dalfopristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes

questions.explanation:
Quinupristin and dalfopristin are a combination of streptogramins and the synergistic activity of 
these drugs has bactericidal action. Quinupristin binds to the 50s subunit of ribosomes and acts similar to macrolides by interfering 
in translocation and inhibiting protein synthesis. Dalfopristin binds to a site nearby, resulting in conformational changes in the 50S ribosome 
thereby increasing the activity of quinupristin. The synergic activity of these drugs can have 
bactericidal action in certain susceptible bacteria. Quinupristin/dalfopristin is active against gram-positive cocci and organisms responsible for 
atypical pneumonia (e.g., M. pneumoniae, Legionella spp., and C. pneumoniae). Quinupristin is a streptogramin B molecule whereas dalfopristin is a streptogramin A molecule.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following binds to the P site of 50s ribosome and inhibits bacterial protein 
synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. 
It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including MRSA. Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%, hence intravenous and 
oral doses are the same for this drug. Linezolid is associated with the side effect of myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, 
pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia). Thrombocytopenia is the most common side effect. Platelet 
count monitoring is done in a patient with linezolid who is at risk of myelosuppression and blood 
dyscrasias. Linezolid also causes serotonin syndrome due to monoamine oxidase(MAO) 
inhibition.

questions.question: Question 14: Linezolid is approved for use in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation:
Linezolid is approved for use in the following conditions: • Vancomycin-resistant E. faecium infections • Methicillin resistance/susceptible S. aureus infections • Community-acquired pneumonia due to S.pneumoniae • Nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus. 470 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is true about tedizolid?

options.a: It is an effective agent for patients with chronic hepatitis B
options.b: Dose is lower for blocking HIV replication than HBV replication

questions.explanation:
Tedizolid is active against gram-positive organisms. Tedizolid belongs to the class of oxazolidinones. It has poor activity against most gram-negative 
bacteria and anaerobes. It inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the P site of the 50S ribosomal 
subunit. It is used for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections, respiratory tract infections caused by 
streptococci, and S. aureus including MRSA. Common adverse effects include myelosuppression leading to anemia, leukopenia, 
thrombocytopenia, and pancytopenia. 471 
Sold by @itachibot Antiretroviral Drugs
